title.children: Last winter Michael was in a caravan. Now he has a place he can call home and it has 'changed everything'

title.children: Police believe Chris made a panicked phone call to family — and then he was gone

items.synopsis: China agrees to drop 80 per cent tariffs on Australian barley, after a long-running and high-profile trade war between the two nations.

title.children: China to ditch controversial Australian barley tariffs

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tariffs were introduced in May 2020 after Beijing accused Australia of selling the grain below the cost of production and subsidising farmers. Today, they've agreed to drop tariffs of 80 per cent applied to Australian barley. The tariffs set off a trade war between the two nations and were widely considered to be a form of retaliation for Australia’s call for an inquiry into the origins of COVID-19. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China drops 80% tariffs on Australian barley

featuredLink.title: China to ditch controversial Australian barley tariffs

props.alt: A field of barely against a blue sky

children.content: (Reuters File)
Tariffs were introduced in May 2020 after Beijing accused Australia of selling the grain below the cost of production and subsidising farmers.
Today, they've agreed to drop tariffs of 80 per cent applied to Australian barley.
The tariffs set off a trade war between the two nations and were widely considered to be a form of retaliation for Australia’s call for an inquiry into the origins of COVID-19.
You can read more here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been received by the Dilak Council of Clan Leaders at the Garma Festival in Arnhem Land, including Djawa Yunupiŋu, one of the key spokespeople and representatives for his people. In the welcome, Yunipiŋu speaks in support of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament. "Prime minister, the councils represents a region of your law, we are here for the future of our children and so that they have a voice in future," he says. "We are their voice and we are an example of what our region can look like. "With us today are our future leaders, who are working with the elders to make a better future and we can tell you that it works and we can tell you that we will vote for the future where there is a Voice in the constitution and that we are saying yes. "Prime minister, Ms Burney and team, as you move towards the referendum this year, when you are responding to difficult questions, or defending this cause, know that we are walking beside you. "We will do this together." The PM is expected to address the media this afternoon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dilak Council of Clan Leaders tells PM: 'We are walking beside you' in Voice campaign

props.alt: An indigenous man with glasses and a green hat speaks at a council table

children.content: Djawa Yunupingu
(ABC News Channel )
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been received by the Dilak Council of Clan Leaders at the Garma Festival in Arnhem Land,
including Djawa Yunupiŋu, one of the key spokespeople and representatives for his people.
In the welcome, Yunipiŋu speaks in support of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament.
"Prime minister, the councils represents a region of your law, we are here for the future of our children and so that they have a voice in future," he says.
"We are their voice and we are an example of what our region can look like.

"With us today are our future leaders, who are working with the elders to make a better future and we can tell you that it works and we can tell you that we will vote for the future where there is a Voice in the constitution and that we are saying yes.
"Prime minister, Ms Burney and team, as you move towards the referendum this year, when you are responding to difficult questions, or defending this cause, know that we are walking beside you.
"We will do this together."
The PM is expected to address the media this afternoon.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier we brought you news of the Canadian province of Alberta withdrawing its bid to host the 2030 Commonwealth Games, citing overwhelming costs. The Commonwealth Games Federation has since released a statement, in which it says it is "sorry to hear that Alberta is no longer developing its bid proposal". It also says it has been reviewing its timeline after the Victorian government withdrew as 2026 host last month. "We thank all those who worked on Alberta’s inspiring and comprehensive plan and we believe the province could be a fantastic host for the Commonwealth Games in the future," the federation says. "We had already been reviewing our selection timeline as a result of the recent Victorian government decision. The dialogue with other potential hosts is ongoing."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Commonwealth Games Federation responds to Canadian province withdrawing from 2030 games

children.content: Earlier we brought you news of the Canadian province of Alberta
withdrawing its bid to host the 2030 Commonwealth Games
, citing overwhelming costs.
The Commonwealth Games Federation has since released a statement, in which it says it is "sorry to hear that Alberta is no longer developing its bid proposal".
It also says it has been reviewing its timeline
after the Victorian government withdrew as 2026 host last month.
"We thank all those who worked on Alberta’s inspiring and comprehensive plan and we believe the province could be a fantastic host for the Commonwealth Games in the future," the federation says.
"We had already been reviewing our selection timeline as a result of the recent Victorian government decision. The dialogue with other potential hosts is ongoing."

title.children: 'No apologies': AFP commissioner rubbishes claims he should have declared friendship with PwC partner

image.altText: Suncorp accepts a $4.9 billion offer from ANZ for its banking business

items.synopsis: Australia's competition watchdog has rejected ANZ's proposed takeover of Suncorp's bank, while local traders await the RBA's latest statement on monetary policy. Follow live.

title.children: ACCC rejects ANZ's $4.9b takeover of Suncorp, Amazon earnings surge, ASX flatlines at open

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: China will lift its tariffs on Australian barley imported into the country, which have been in place since May 2020. As the government flagged earlier this week, Australia had been expecting the 80 per cent anti-dumping tariffs to be removed, with an August 11 deadline looming. Now, China's Ministry of Commerce has confirmed the news, which will come into effect tomorrow. The two countries reached an agreement to end the trade dispute back in April. It's the latest step in an improving relationship between Australia and China, with coal imports resuming in January and timber imports also back on the cards. Despite the size of the Chinese market, the steep tariffs didn't wipe out Australia barley growers, who turned to other markets.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia-China barley bust-up over after 3 years

children.content: China will lift its tariffs on Australian barley
imported into the country, which have been in place since May 2020.
As
the government flagged earlier this week
Australia had been expecting the 80 per cent anti-dumping tariffs to be removed
, with an August 11 deadline looming.
Now,
China's Ministry of Commerce
has confirmed the news, which will come into effect tomorrow.
The two countries reached an agreement to end the trade dispute back in April.
(ABC Great Southern: Tom Edwards)
It's the latest step in an improving relationship between Australia and China, with coal imports resuming in January and timber imports also back on the cards.
Despite the size of the Chinese market, the steep tariffs didn't wipe out Australia barley growers, who turned to other markets.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello from the big state - I'm popping in with an update on the price of our biggest export commodity, iron ore. It has been heading south and is now ever so close to $US100 a tonne. Take a look at this chart compiled by economists at CBA that shows the price movement since August 2020. The spot price for the commodity peaked in about May 2021 about $US240 a tonne. The price plunge links back to demand from China. Spot prices are down about 11 per cent since July 25. CBA's Mining and Energy Commodities expert, Vivek Dhar writes: "Markets are concerned that policymakers may not follow through with any meaningful support for China's commodity-intensive economy following the semi-annual economic conference attended by China's top leaders ('Politburo'). The conference, which took place in late July, saw China's top leaders pledge to "strength counter cyclical policies", where an "adjustment" would be made to the restrictions on the property sector. Policymakers even reportedly talked of bringing forward infrastructure spending to help support the economy. These announcements though lacked details such as targets and timelines ." China's property sector accounts for 35-40% of China's steel consumption. Most of China's property sector indicators have worsened through the first half of 2023. "It's challenging to see how policymakers turn-around China's property sector, particularly given the extent of supply and demand side issues that are weighing on the sector at present. A number of factors began last year when China's COVID-zero policy crippled household balance sheets and saw a number of property developers default. We think steel demand from China's property sector will likely only stabilise next year. The rapid fall in iron ore prices over the last week raises downside risks to our forecast for iron ore prices to fall to $US100/t by Q4 2023. " Iron ore miners like BHP, Rio Tinto and FMG will often sayu they're playing the long game and don't watch spot prices, but I'm pretty sure they'll be keeping a close eye on this activity in China. It's also worth pointing out, $US100 it still much higher than the government's long term price estimates of $US55 a tonne .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Iron ore miners on alert as the commodity price nudges $US100

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Another interesting takeout from the cost of living committee was a discussion between Treasury and Senators on our housing crisis. Senator Karen Grogan began her line of questioning by asking Treasury officials whether they were concerned with housing supply and what their forecasts were for the sector, or whether it was simply house prices they were focused on. Treasury's Luke Yeaman said they keep a close eye on both the construction sector and rental market — especially the latter given it has a direct impact on inflation. He said there had been "some divergence" between medium density apartments versus standalone homes, and there had been a large surge in approvals for standalone homes because of the HomeBuilder scheme during COVID. Supply chain issues however are still having an impact on the construction sector, which is in turn affecting the housing market, because while there is a large pipeline of new housing coming online, it's much slower than expected because of those construction issues, he said. Senator Grogan asked whether Treasury expects its forecasted housing supply to be on track, to which Mr Yeaman responded that they are expecting medium density housing to alleviate pressure in the market in the next 12 to 18 months, especially with strong growth in migration. Treasury's Assistant Secretary for Housing, Kerren Crosthwaite, followed up Mr Yeaman by saying they expect some easing in the rental market when more social and affordable housing is built. Ms Crosthwaite said currently there are more people in the private rental market because there has been a reduction in available public housing. She said between 2011 and 2022, there was a reduction in social housing from 4.8% to 4.1%, which came back to state and local governments across the jurisdictions and their respective decisions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasury expects some housing market pressure to ease in next 18 months

Senator Karen Grogan
began her line of questioning by asking
Treasury officials whether they were concerned with housing supply and what their forecasts were for the sector, or whether it was simply house prices they were focused on.
Treasury's
Luke Yeaman
said they keep a close eye on both the construction sector and rental market — especially the latter given it has a direct impact on inflation.
He said there had been "some divergence" between medium density apartments versus standalone homes, and there had been
a large surge in approvals for standalone homes because of the HomeBuilder scheme
during COVID.
Supply chain issues however are still having an impact on the construction sector, which is in turn affecting the housing market, because
while there is a large pipeline of new housing coming online, it's much slower than expected because of those construction issues
, he said.
Senator Grogan asked whether Treasury expects its forecasted housing supply to be on track, to which Mr Yeaman responded that they are
expecting medium density housing to alleviate pressure in the market in the next 12 to 18 months
, especially with strong growth in migration.
Treasury's Assistant Secretary for Housing,
Kerren Crosthwaite,
followed up Mr Yeaman by saying they expect some
easing in the rental market when more social and affordable housing is built
Ms Crosthwaite said currently there are
more people in the private rental market because there has been a reduction in available public housing
She said between 2011 and 2022, there was a
reduction in social housing from 4.8% to 4.1%
, which came back to state and local governments across the jurisdictions and their respective decisions.
